nexttext: The following expansion ($\rho={\alpha}{\hbar}/mc$)

leads to the functions $\psi({\rho})$ in the spacetime independent $\rho$-representation.
 In \cite{Kad}, in the framework of a two-particle equation of the quasipotential type, the variable $\rho$ was interpreted as the relativistic generalization of a relative coordinate. Quasipotential models of a relativistic oscillator  were first considered in \cite{Atak}.  

The $\rho$-representation or  the $\rho{\bf n}$-representation ($\vert{\bf n}\vert=1)$ may  also be used in a so-called generalized Schr\"odinger (GS) picture in which the analogs of the Schr\"odinger operators of a particle are independent of both the time and the space coordinates t, ${\bf x}$ in different representations \cite{Fri1}. In the GS picture we have two spacetime independent representation of the Poincar\'e algebra; the ${\bf p}$ and the $\rho{\bf n}$-representation.  The use of the $\rho{\bf n}$-representation in this picture  makes it possible to describe extendent objects like strings.  In the $\rho$-representation the Hamilton operator $H$ and the momentum operator $P $ of the particle have the form (${\tilde\lambda}=\frac{\hbar}{mc}$)
prevtext: The following expansion ($\rho={\alpha}{\hbar}/mc$)

leads to the functions $\psi({\rho})$ in the spacetime independent $\rho$-representation.
 In \cite{Kad}, in the framework of a two-particle equation of the quasipotential type, the variable $\rho$ was interpreted as the relativistic generalization of a relative coordinate. Quasipotential models of a relativistic oscillator  were first considered in \cite{Atak}.  

The $\rho$-representation or  the $\rho{\bf n}$-representation ($\vert{\bf n}\vert=1)$ may  also be used in a so-called generalized Schr\"odinger (GS) picture in which the analogs of the Schr\"odinger operators of a particle are independent of both the time and the space coordinates t, ${\bf x}$ in different representations \cite{Fri1}. In the GS picture we have two spacetime independent representation of the Poincar\'e algebra; the ${\bf p}$ and the $\rho{\bf n}$-representation.  The use of the $\rho{\bf n}$-representation in this picture  makes it possible to describe extendent objects like strings.  In the $\rho$-representation the Hamilton operator $H$ and the momentum operator $P $ of the particle have the form (${\tilde\lambda}=\frac{\hbar}{mc}$)

nexttext: It follows that  the  spacetime coordinates appear in the states in  the $\rho{\bf n}$ and in the ${\bf p}$-representation. We have a metamorphosis of the  Heisenberg's uncertainty relation ${\Delta}x{\cdot}{\Delta}p\geq{\hbar}/2$. From $\lbrack{\rho},P\rbrack=i{\hbar}H/mc^2$ in (\ref{1.4}) follows that insted of ${\Delta}x{\cdot}{\Delta}p\geq{\hbar}/2$, we have
prevtext: where $\psi(p,t,x)=\psi(p)exp[-i(tp_0-xp)\hbar]$. For the functions $\psi({\rho},t,x)$ and $\psi(p,t,x)$ we have

nexttext:
The GS picture may be used in a quantum theory of gravity in which objects need a sharply defined frame.
In the papers \cite{Fri2},  this picture was used  to describe the motion of  a particle in anti-de Sitter and de Sitter spacetime.  It was found that in the cases of d = 2 and d=4, the spacetime independent operators of a particle in  an external field  induce operators ${K}(t,x^{i})$ which are related to Killing vectors  of the AdS (dS) spacetime. Equivalently to (\ref{1.7}), we have $(d=4;a=1,2,...10;$ $\lbrace{x^{i}\rbrace}$, $i=1,2,3.)$
prevtext: It follows that  the  spacetime coordinates appear in the states in  the $\rho{\bf n}$ and in the ${\bf p}$-representation. We have a metamorphosis of the  Heisenberg's uncertainty relation ${\Delta}x{\cdot}{\Delta}p\geq{\hbar}/2$. From $\lbrack{\rho},P\rbrack=i{\hbar}H/mc^2$ in (\ref{1.4}) follows that insted of ${\Delta}x{\cdot}{\Delta}p\geq{\hbar}/2$, we have

nexttext:
Here $\widetilde{\Phi}$ denotes the wave function of the particle. The operators  ${K}_a(t,x^{i})$ satisfy  the same commutation rules as  the spacetime independent operators $B _a({\rho},{\bf n})$, except for the minus signs on the right-hand sides.  Eq. (\ref{1.9}) are valid for any d. In the present paper we use these equations to describe the motion of a particle in $AdS_3$ spacetime. In the case of d = 3 we need  six spacetime independent operators of the particle.  In Sect. 2  we will now show that the operators of  a relativistic  model of the two-dimensional quantum harmonic oscillator in the ${\rho}{\bf n}$-representation can be used in  Eq. (\ref{1.9}).  This  will allow us to obtain an exact expression for the energy  levels of the particle and an expression for  the spectrum of the $AdS_3$ radius.

\section{} In the two-dimensional  momentum  space representation, the first Casimir operator of the Lorentz group ${C_1}={\bf N}^2-{\bf L}^2$, has the eigenfuctions
($p^2_0-c^2p^2_1-c^2p^2_2=m^2c^4$)
prevtext:
The GS picture may be used in a quantum theory of gravity in which objects need a sharply defined frame.
In the papers \cite{Fri2},  this picture was used  to describe the motion of  a particle in anti-de Sitter and de Sitter spacetime.  It was found that in the cases of d = 2 and d=4, the spacetime independent operators of a particle in  an external field  induce operators ${K}(t,x^{i})$ which are related to Killing vectors  of the AdS (dS) spacetime. Equivalently to (\ref{1.7}), we have $(d=4;a=1,2,...10;$ $\lbrace{x^{i}\rbrace}$, $i=1,2,3.)$
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{K}_{a}(t,x^{i})\widetilde{\Phi}({\rho},{\bf n},t,x^{i})=B_{a}({\rho},{\bf n})%
\widetilde{\Phi}({\rho},{\bf n},t,x^{i})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>𝐧</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>𝐧</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>𝐧</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $(n_1={\cos\varphi}, n_2={\sin\varphi})$.

The Hamilton operator  and the momentum operators of the particle defined on the functions $\xi^{*}(\bf p,\rho,\bf n)$ have the form \cite{Nag}
prevtext:
Here $\widetilde{\Phi}$ denotes the wave function of the particle. The operators  ${K}_a(t,x^{i})$ satisfy  the same commutation rules as  the spacetime independent operators $B _a({\rho},{\bf n})$, except for the minus signs on the right-hand sides.  Eq. (\ref{1.9}) are valid for any d. In the present paper we use these equations to describe the motion of a particle in $AdS_3$ spacetime. In the case of d = 3 we need  six spacetime independent operators of the particle.  In Sect. 2  we will now show that the operators of  a relativistic  model of the two-dimensional quantum harmonic oscillator in the ${\rho}{\bf n}$-representation can be used in  Eq. (\ref{1.9}).  This  will allow us to obtain an exact expression for the energy  levels of the particle and an expression for  the spectrum of the $AdS_3$ radius.

\section{} In the two-dimensional  momentum  space representation, the first Casimir operator of the Lorentz group ${C_1}={\bf N}^2-{\bf L}^2$, has the eigenfuctions
($p^2_0-c^2p^2_1-c^2p^2_2=m^2c^4$)

We now turn to a brief discussion of the operators ${K}_a(t,x^{i})$ in (\ref{1.9}). 
The explicit forms of the six operators ${K}_a(t,x^{i})$ depend on the realisation in terms of the spacetime coordinates. We have the problem of determining  observables in  GS picture. In order to interpret the operator $\hat{P_0}$ as  Hamilton operator, we chose the following realisation ($t$, $x_1$, $x_2$ ($x_1=r\cos\widetilde{\varphi}$,  $x_2=r\sin\widetilde{\varphi}$,  $i=1,2$)),

nexttext:
For the $AdS_3$ radius $\kappa=c/{\omega}$, we have ${\kappa}_M=\sqrt{(M^2-2M+3/4)}$ $\hbar/mc$.

\section{}
In this paper we have shown that a generalized Schr\"odinger picture may be used to describe a  relativistic particle in  a 3-dimensional anti-de Sitter spacetime.  A specific feature of this picture is that the frame itself becomes dynamical. It was observed  that in this picture we have a metamorphosis of the  Heisenberg's uncertainty relations.  Finally,  we have shown that, the energy of the particle  and the anti-de Sitter radius are discrete. We hope that the mathematical formalism that has been presented here will be employed for solving problems in quantum physics, astrophysics, and cosmology.
